issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: Kernel, ramdisk images are not owned by the accounts who register them

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Kernel and Ramdisk images disappear from euca-describe-images

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
From a bran new install from source, I uploaded 2 images with their respectives ERI and EKI. One of the 2 image was the load balancing image. After the upload of the images, euca-describe-images displayed the following results:

{code}
[root@h-01 vic-centos-img]# euca-describe-images
IMAGE   eki-226D3CA3    vic_kvm_kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml   280787410802    available       private         i386    kernel                          instance-store
IMAGE   eki-B28738A0    elb_image_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml 280787410802    available       private         i386    kernel                          instance-store
IMAGE   emi-61433A04    vic_kvm_image/vic-centos.img.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       private         i386    machine eki-226D3CA3    eri-C5D43677            instance-store
IMAGE   eri-C5D43677    vic_kvm_ramdisk/initrd.img-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       private         i386    ramdisk                         instance-store
IMAGE   emi-60C2368E    tmpayewwtqfdv/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       public          i386    machine eki-91253DB6    eri-E9063923            instance-store
IMAGE   eri-69273A68    elb_image_bucket/initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img.manifest.xml   280787410802    available       private         i386    ramdisk                         instance-store
[root@h-01 vic-centos-img]#
{code}

I proceeded to generate a key and to run the non-ELB image with this key. Once the euca-run-instance command completed, the euca-describe-images command reported the EKI and ERI missing for this EMI.

{code}
[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images
IMAGE   eki-B28738A0    elb_image_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml 280787410802    available       private         i386    kernel                          instance-store
IMAGE   emi-61433A04    vic_kvm_image/vic-centos.img.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       private         i386    machine eki-226D3CA3    eri-C5D43677            instance-store
IMAGE   emi-60C2368E    tmpayewwtqfdv/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       public          i386    machine eki-91253DB6    eri-E9063923            instance-store
IMAGE   eri-69273A68    elb_image_bucket/initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img.manifest.xml   280787410802    available       private         i386    ramdisk                         instance-store
{code}

Although these 2 ERI and EKI are missing, I can call them explicitly.

{code}
[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images eki-226D3CA3
IMAGE	eki-226D3CA3	vic_kvm_kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml	000000000001	available	private		i386	kernel				instance-store
[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images eri-C5D43677
IMAGE	eri-C5D43677	vic_kvm_ramdisk/initrd.img-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml	000000000001	available	private		i386	ramdisk				instance-store
[root@h-01 ELB]# 
{code}
fields.summary: Kernel and Ramdisk images disappear from euca-describe-images

FYI, I still have a setup up in this condition if you need more information or want to poke at it. The CLC/WS is at 10.111.5.1, the CC/SC is at 10.111.5.3 and NC is at 10.111.5.5. The latest eucarc credentials are under /root/ELB/eucarc.

Looking at the setup with [~tony] yesterday, we noticed that the following EMI is also wrong?

{code}
IMAGE	emi-60C2368E	tmpayewwtqfdv/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml	280787410802	available	public	i386	machine	eki-91253DB6	eri-E9063923		instance-store		
{code}

When registering this image, here's the command I used from the history:

{code}
euca-bundle-image -i vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64  --kernel true -d .
euca-upload-bundle -b elb_image_bucket -m vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml
euca-register -n elb-image-kernel elb_image_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml
eki-B28738A0

euca-bundle-image -i initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img  --ramdisk true -d .
euca-upload-bundle -b elb_image_bucket -m initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img.manifest.xml
euca-register -n elb-image-ramdisk elb_image_bucket/initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img.manifest.xml
eri-69273A68

euca-bundle-image -i eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-48.130411git1a55ab3.img --ramdisk eri-69273A68 --kernel eki-B28738A0 -d .
This command failed because of wrong image name

euca-bundle-image -i eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-56.130422git6aaad26.img --ramdisk eri-69273A68 --kernel eki-B28738A0 -d .
euca-upload-bundle -b elb_image_bucket -m eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-56.130422git6aaad26.img.manifest.xml 
This last command failed.

euca-register -n elb-image eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-56.130422git6aaad26.img.manifest.xml 
euca-upload-bundle -b elb-image -m eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-56.130422git6aaad26.img.manifest.xml 
euca-describe-images 

[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images
IMAGE   eki-B28738A0    elb_image_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml 280787410802    available       private         i386    kernel                          instance-store
IMAGE   emi-60C2368E    tmpayewwtqfdv/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml       280787410802    available       public          i386    machine eki-91253DB6    eri-E9063923            instance-store
IMAGE   eri-69273A68    elb_image_bucket/initramfs-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.img.manifest.xml   280787410802    available       private         i386    ramdisk                         instance-store
{code}

notice how now the EMI's registered ERI and EKI are invalid???

Last night, [~tony] re-registered the bad image and we are not missing more images from the euca-describe-images command:

{code}
[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images 
IMAGE	emi-61433A04	vic_kvm_image/vic-centos.img.manifest.xml	280787410802	available	private	i386	machine	eki-226D3CA3	eri-C5D43677		instance-store		
IMAGE	emi-60C2368E	tmpayewwtqfdv/precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-ext3.img.manifest.xml	280787410802	available	public	i386	machine	eki-91253DB6	eri-E9063923		instance-store		
IMAGE	emi-D4E7331F	elb_image_bucket/eucalyptus-load-balancer-image-devel-1.0.0-56.130422git6aaad26.img.manifest.xml	280787410802	available	private	x86_64	machine	eki-B28738A0	eri-69273A68		instance-store		
[root@h-01 ELB]# 
{code}

I only uploaded 2 images to this setup. The first is the ELB image found under /disk1/storage/elb-image/ and an image cooked by [~viglesias] found under /disk1/storage/vic-centos-img/

[~sjones], using the "-a" option listed all images. In regards to the "only the ones they own or have explicit launch permissions for." comment, I'm not sure I got it right. My understanding is that all images have been uploaded by the eucalyptus/admin user and displayed without the "-a" option at one time and randomly started to disappear from this listing.

The output with "-a"

{code}
[root@h-01 ELB]# euca-describe-images -a
IMAGE	eki-226D3CA3	vic_kvm_kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.28-11-generic.manifest.xml	000000000001	available	private	i386	kernel				instance-store		
IMAGE	eki-B28738A0	elb_image_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.32-358.2.1.el6.x86_64.manifest.xml	000000000001	available	private	i386	kernel				instance-store

Emis.LookupKernel and Emis.LookupRamdisk set the owner to nobody (id 1) during the look up that occurs when running an instance.

It is surprising that this has not been noticed before, though it is more obvious after the fix for EUCA-4345. Since kernels and ramdisks are not owned by regular accounts the impact is probably lessened.

The fix is either to not set the owner, or to evict the image from the persistence session so it is not updated (Entities.evict)

[~decker] is there a reason to set the owner to nobody for a kernel/ramdisk?

[~sjones], just to confirm. I uploaded a kernel, ramdisk and image. I then did a euca-describe-images which showed me all 3. Then I ran an instance with the image and later did a euca-describe-images and both kernel and ramdisk disappeared from the listing but will show if I use "-a".

[~awithrow], we need to ensure the necessary changes to image management are called out in the release notes and also in the documentation for 3.3.0.

The fix for this issue means that the cloud administrator should now ensure that kernel and ramdisk images are public, either individually:

  euca-modify-image-attribute -l -a all eki-8B733D62

after registration, or globally:

  euca-modify-property -p cloud.images.defaultvisibility=true

prior to registration.

Verified that running an instance no longer changes image ownership to nobody. [~chuck] please review the verification steps to ensure they cover the reported issue.
